lines.text: I love you, Sarah. There are some things that can't be written... in a letter. I'm not good with words.

You're fine with words. I never thought you'd come. I dreamed about it at night when the sea sounded like wind through the grasses. I thought about it at night when Caleb had bad dreams. I saw your face everywhere, Jacob, everywhere. I'd look at the sea and see your face there, and in the sky. When I looked at Anna and Caleb you were there. Once in the street I saw somebody that looked like you and I rushed after him. Once I met the train because something told me maybe you'd be there... but I never thought you'd come. Here I was like a child come home to my beautiful sea and I should've been happy but I was frightened. And I am frightened because... this terrible love for you is so strong I, I've never known such a thing before.

[whispered]
I know.
I never thought you'd come.

[Jacob kisses Sarah]
They're kissing and hugging!
Of course they are.
Once Matty asked me how long I'd stay here and I know now. I came to stay long enough to say goodbye. I think, Jacob, our baby should be born on the prairie. It's the right thing.
[pauses]
You were right - some things can't be written in a letter. You, you said it once; sometimes words aren't good enough... Jacob?
[he smiles, they laugh and hug]
Leaving?
[Maggie climbs out of wagon and they go out to field behind the wagon]
I hate this land.

[Wiping eyes, voice breaking]
Sarah.
No, I mean it. I don't have to love it like Jacob. Like Matthew. They give it everything. Everything, and it betrays them.
[Voice cracks]
It gives them nothing back. You know Jacob once told me his name is written in this land, well, mine isn't. IT isn't.

They don't know anywhere else. You know, you are like the prairie lark. It sings from high in the air to tell the other birds it's there, and then it drops to earth. But you have not come to earth, Sarah. You don't have to love this land, but if you don't you won't survive. Jacob IS right. You have to write your name in it to live here.
[Sarah walks away upset]
I think she's something more than fat, Sarah.
What?
What does Papa mean?
Kittens. He means kittens.
I could've been gone. I could have gone for water when this happened.
But you weren't gone.
You might've been here alone with the children. You have to go, Sarah. You have to take Anna and Caleb away from here.
No, Jacob.
Sarah, there's no water. There's NOTHING here for Anna and Caleb. I can't have them here. They can't go alone.
We won't leave you. I won't go. I can't go.
I know, but you and the children have to go. Do you understand? Sarah, this land is my life. Like your father and the sea. I can't go away from it. But you have to. But without you, I-
[they hug]
What will happen to us?
We'll write letters. We've written letters before.
Well, I wrote you a letter, but we had to leave so quickly, I didn't have a chance to mail it. I wrote about the drought, and the fire.
And did the letter say that you are pregnant?
[Sarah is flabbergasted]
Excuse me, could you tell me where the Wheaton's live?
Get in, I'll take you there. I'm Chub...
Chubbers Horatio Umberto Bell. I'm Jacob Witting.
Jacob Witting, yeah. About time you got here.
Papa!
Get back on the porch and stay there!
What are you going to do when we're gone, Papa?
I'll miss you.
Matty, someone's here. Who is that? Matty, come quickly. I think...
It's him. Harriet, It's him.
I've never been in a car before.
About time you were. Wanna drive?

[Nervously]
No.
Lou works with animals.
Lou works with the veterinarian, and Harriet may never get over that.
I can't pay you, Jess.
I didn't come to get paid. I came to help.
What's so funny?
We had a lovely day.
Catch any fish?
No.
Tell me. You gonna tell me? Tell me.

[Giggling]
Aw, it's a secret.
Oh-oh, a Chub secret? Oh, I will make a deal with you. You tell me the Chub secret, and I will tell you Chub's real name. You can blackmail him.
What's blackmail?
A criminal act, my dear.
Come along, Caleb. Let us go to the porch, where I will reveal, only to you mind you, Chub's real name.

Someday when times are better and there's money to be earned, I'll buy a place like this. My Papa used to say a man is rich if he has land. People, they come and go, but the land is always there. Got the whole world under your feet.
The whole world. That's what I used to think.
The whole world, Jacob.
What's dashing?
That's what I'm doing, right now. Dashing into the water.
You are?
You wanna come? I'm going skinny-dipping.
Lou! Not in front of the children!
Harriet, what is you do each evening, when everyone's in bed?
Lou!
No clothes on?
[Runs after her]
You mean you're gonna swim all naked?
Everyone goes skinny-dipping.

[Calling]
Anna! Anna! Come here! In the moonlight she looks like a big fish!
[Everyone laughs]
William, do you remember Papa singing a song about a skylark?
Like a skylark, Sarah sings. You never stayed still, you know, you were always in the trees, climbing rocks. He used to call you his skylark, and he said you'd never come to earth.
